segments.content: Reginald Johnson had been a Shakespearean actor before the Second World War broke out. Like most of his generation, he put his own dreams on hold to serve the nation in its time of crisis. His grandson, though, has dedicated his whole life to defence as a soldier, a scholar and a senior civil servant. Rob is fiercely loyal to his country and would never want to talk it down, but he's become increasingly worried about the state of the UK's defences after a prolonged period of peace that's seen the government and society forget what it means to be ready for war. It's a concern he raised while seconded to the Ministry of Defence. My job was to try to alert colleagues to what was going on and where the gaps were. What I found, actually, was that many, many people agreed with me. They knew we were in the position we are. But the response often was, look, government's about choice, and the government of the day and the governments we've had have all made the same choice, which is that we're going to invest in health and education and roads and growth, not in defence. Resilience was second nature during the Cold War, but when the Soviet Union collapsed, successive prime ministers spent less on the armed forces and more on other priorities. European allies did the same, all seeing this as a peace dividend, while gambling that the United States would still protect them if things went wrong. But the threat posed by Russia never really went away. And now, under Donald Trump, America's support to its partners in NATO no longer feels so guaranteed. I think it's common sense, right? If they don't pay, I'm not going to defend them. No, I'm not going to defend them. I got into a lot of heat when I said that. You said, oh, he's violating NATO. With Europe weak and Russia on a war footing, it's a perfect storm. I'm Debra Haines, the security and defence editor at Sky News. I've been a journalist for the past two and a half decades and can tell you that Rob isn't alone with his concerns. Pretty much everyone I speak to inside the military says the UK has allowed its defences to shrink too far and has lost the kind of national resilience it once had during the Cold War. But because we live in a country that generally feels pretty safe, it's perhaps hard to understand why or even whether that matters. It made me wonder, what if we simulate an emergency and find out how the UK might respond? Whatever the outcome, it would at least bring to life the reality of the threat.

segments.content: Governments around the world use war games to run through scenarios and test responses for literally anything from health emergencies to World War III. Typically, they're conducted in secret, with the blue and the red teams pitched against each other, each able to act as they choose. In our scenario, though, the red team, while free to make some choices, is already aware of the key steps it will take. By contrast, the blue team knows very little about the scenario and will have to respond to whatever comes its way. As well as running the show, Rob is playing the role of what's known as the Chair of the Joint Intelligence Committee, or JIC Chair. He'll share updates from the UK's spy agencies, MI6, MI5 and GCHQ, as well as Defence Intelligence, which is part of the Ministry of Defence, or MOD. There are lots of acronyms in the military and the security world. I'll try to spell them out whenever they come up. With the drama about to start... ...Ben and his team have assembled around a long table... ...in the largest of the basement rooms We're now going to open the exercise In the real world, it's a Tuesday morning in early April. In the war game, it's almost six months in the future, and the government is in crisis mode. To set the scene, we've mocked up some rolling news reports from an imagined UK television station. Everyone stops talking and listens. It's 8am on Monday 29th September, our top story this morning. Travel chaos on the railways and the roads after a major power cut left parts of England and Wales without electricity. Multiple train stations have been forced to close to passengers this morning after what the National Grid is describing as an issue with two generators. Reports are also coming in of problems on the roads. Transport for London says some traffic lights in the capital are out of action and police officers may be called in to manage certain junctions. The disruption comes just three days after simultaneous fires broke out at ferry terminals in Plymouth and Portsmouth, halting Channel Ferry crossings over the weekend. The Home Office says counter-terrorism officers are now investigating the fires as a precautionary measure. The security sources say they haven't ruled out foul play. Last year, the heads of MI6 and the CIA accused Moscow of waging a reckless campaign of sabotage across Europe. Russia has previously denied involvement in any sabotage attacks. And there could, of course, be a perfectly innocent explanation for this transport chaos. For now, the cause is unclear. Then, two days later, this happens. It's 8am on Wednesday, the 1st of October. Our top story. Explosions have ripped through a major naval base in northern Russia, killing and wounding dozens of personnel. The Russian president has suggested the attack at Severomorsk was linked to the UK and has vowed revenge. The British government has yet to comment, but Downing Street sources have strongly rejected the allegation of any UK involvement. We'll bring you more as we get it. As tensions grow between Moscow and London over the next few days, British police make a shocking discovery. It's 4pm on Sunday 5th October, our top story. The Ministry of Defence says two F-35 pilots have been found shot dead in Norfolk. The circumstances of the deaths are not clear and military police are investigating. Both pilots are part of 617 Squadron, which fly the UK's most sophisticated F-35 warplanes out of RAF Marham. In other news, Moscow has recalled its ambassador to London, saying Britain is now considered an unfriendly state. The extraordinary move follows the deadly blasts at a major Russian naval base that the Kremlin has claimed were linked to the UK, but without providing evidence.
